episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a range of fascinating topics, including the surprising sales history of "The Great Gatsby," Archimedes' inventive defense mechanisms, the peculiar eating habits of the black swallower fish, and the unusual use of horse urine in cathedral restoration.

facts.fact: In 1944, the book The Great Gatsby sold 120 copies. In 1945, the number of copies printed was 155,000.
To protect the city of Syracuse, Archimedes invented a giant claw that could lift enemy ships clean out of the water.
Most black swallower fish specimens died because they ate too much, and their stomachs exploded.
There is a cathedral in Norway currently restoring its rooftop with large amounts of urine from a retired field horse called Norik.
